misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles for an acceleration problem instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program is implemented for an average-acceleration task: it prompts for v0, v1, and t and reads three double values instead of reading five integers as required to compute the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should read v0, v1, and t as doubles to compute average acceleration for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this assignment, the program must read exactly five integer values from the user (e.g., using nextInt), regardless of any physics context, because the goal is to sum only the even numbers among those five inputs.
symptoms: Prompt text mentions v0, v1, and t instead of five integers
Only three values are read from input
nextDouble is used instead of nextInt
No way to provide five separate integers as required
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or pasted a solution for a different textbook problem about average acceleration and did not adapt the input handling to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the three double inputs (v0, v1, t) with code that reads five int values from the user. Use variable names and a prompt that clearly refer to five integers, and prefer nextInt for integer input.
related_concepts: Designing prompts that match required input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The variable names, prompt, and number/type of inputs clearly match a standard acceleration problem and not the required 'sum of 5 even integers' task.

evidence.note: The program reads three double values (v0, v1, t) for an acceleration calculation instead of five integers as required.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process the required five inputs
misconceptions.description: The code reads a fixed set of three values without any loop or repeated structure, so it cannot iterate over five numbers or generalize the processing of multiple inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: Since I only need v0, v1, and t for acceleration, I can read each value once without a loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should use a loop (for or while) that runs exactly five times, reading each integer and processing it in turn, rather than manually reading a different set of variables for another task.
symptoms: No for or while loop in main
Only three input operations are present
Cannot naturally extend to processing five integers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a completely different algorithm (average acceleration) which naturally uses a constant number of reads, so they did not design or consider a looping structure for five inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop that iterates five times. Inside the loop, read an int from the user and apply the even-check and sum logic. Remove the acceleration-specific code that only reads three values.
related_concepts: Iterating a fixed number of times
Mapping problem requirements to control structures
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no loop anywhere in the code, and the entire structure is oriented around a one-shot physics formula rather than repeated processing of five integers.

evidence.note: The entire main method contains no for or while loop; it performs a fixed sequence of three reads and one calculation.

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional check for even numbers using modulo
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (e.g., with n % 2 == 0). Instead, it directly applies a physics formula to v0, v1, and t, so there is no filtering of even vs. odd values at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: For this task, I just need to plug v0, v1, and t into the acceleration formula, so no conditional logic is required.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To solve the given problem, the program must test each of the five integers and include it in the sum only if it is even, typically by using a conditional with the modulo operator: if (n % 2 == 0) { sum += n; }.
symptoms: No if statement related to checking parity
No use of the % operator
All input values (v0, v1, t) are treated as continuous doubles rather than integers to be tested for evenness
misconceptions.root_cause: The student is solving a different problem (average acceleration) which does not involve parity checks, so they did not consider using modulo or any conditional logic about even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an if statement inside the input-processing loop to check if the current integer n is even using n % 2 == 0 before adding it to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditional or modulo use anywhere; all arithmetic is a straightforward division for acceleration.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Only an acceleration formula is computed; there is no if-statement or modulo operation to select even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Computes and prints acceleration instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description: Rather than maintaining an accumulator for the sum of even numbers and printing it, the code computes an average acceleration value from v1, v0, and t and prints a physics-related message.
misconceptions.student_belief: The goal is to calculate and display the average acceleration given v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should maintain an integer sum variable initialized to 0, add each even integer input to this sum, and finally print the total with a message like "Sum of even numbers: X".
symptoms: No sum or accumulator variable exists
Output message refers to average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
Final result is a double from a physics formula, not an integer sum
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a complete solution to a different assignment about physics, so they never introduced an accumulator pattern or the required problem-specific output format.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an int sum = 0; before the loop, add even numbers to it as they are read, and at the end print the sum with the specified wording: "Sum of even numbers: " followed by the sum.
related_concepts: Initialization and updating state in a loop
Formatting output messages to match specifications
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Variable names and the printed string clearly reference acceleration, and there is no accumulator or sum-related output anywhere in the program.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: The calculation and output are for average acceleration, not for a sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Used 'double' data type incorrectly

misconceptions.name: Reading wrong number and type of inputs
misconceptions.description: Student reads only 3 values of type double instead of 5 integers, and prompts for physics variables (v0, v1, t) rather than generic integers.

misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code from an entirely different assignment (physics/acceleration problem) instead of the sum-of-evens problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Verify the correct program was submitted. Q1 should read 5 integers (not 3 doubles). Start fresh with: 'Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in); System.out.print("Enter 5 integers: "); int[] nums = new int[5]; for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { nums[i] = input.nextInt(); }'

misconceptions.name: Missing loop for processing multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: Code reads fixed values without a loop structure, making it impossible to efficiently process variable or multiple inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that hard-coding individual variable reads is acceptable, or did not consider that a loop is needed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process multiple inputs (especially when the count is greater than 1), use a loop structure such as a for-loop. This allows scalable, clean code.
symptoms: No for-loop, while-loop, or do-while loop present
Three separate input statements written explicitly
Code cannot adapt if the number of inputs changes
Not following the 'efficient handling' requirement in the rubric
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for a different problem that only requires 3 inputs, not general iteration logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a for-loop: 'for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); if (num % 2 == 0) { sum += num; } }' This loop reads, checks, and accumulates in one structure.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The complete absence of any loop structure is obvious and non-negotiable for this task.

evidence.note: Hard-coded three separate variable assignments instead of a loop structure
